                      Executive Summary

           Royster-Clark Nitrogen - Meredosia, IL



A.  Introduction:

The  Royster-Clark  Nitrogen terminal in Meredosia  receives

fertilizers from barges, stores the fertilizer in tanks, and

loads  trucks.  The facility has one anhydrous ammonia  tank

and  four  urea  ammonium  nitrate (UAN)  liquid  fertilizer

storage tanks.

.

B.  Accidental Release Record:



The Royster-Clark Nitrogen, Meredosia Terminal, has an

excellent safety record with no deaths or serious injuries

to facility personnel since it was constructed in 1964.



The facility safety record is the direct result of continued

emphasis on safety by management, employees, contractors,

and truck drivers.  There have not been any releases from

the terminal that meet the description of an RMP accidental

release.



C.   General Accidental Release Prevention  Policies And

  Activities:



Royster-Clark Nitrogen believes safety and concern for the

environment must be second nature to all employees and

contractor personnel.



The entire Royster-Clark Nitrogen team works together to

ensure the facility is in compliance with OSHA's Process

Safety Management standards and the accident prevention

programs are continuously improved.  A networked computer

management system is utilized to provide our employees with

the necessary tools and records to maintain the safety of

the process.  This teamwork is an integral part in the

safety efforts of this facility.



Accident release prevention steps include the fourteen

element program for Process Safety Management, a management

system, corporate oversight of the facility, and a focus on

continuous improvement.



Royster-Clark Nitrogen encourages all employees to

participate in the facility's safety program.  Examples of

employee participation include participation in Process

Hazard Analyses, cooperative training, updating

of operating

procedures, and emergency response activities.





Royster-Clark Nitrogen has well established practices and

procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems,

relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, compressors, and

emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.

This program includes:



     1.   training

     2.   written operating procedures

     3.   inspections and tests in accordance with recognized

       standards,

     4.   correction of deficiencies, and

     5.   quality assurance



In combination, these activities form a system that

maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Maintenance personnel receive training on  (1) an overview

of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) emergency

response plans, and (4) applicable safe work practices to

help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe

manner.  Written procedures help ensure that work is

performed in a consistent manner, conforms to generally

accepted standards, and provides a basis for training.

Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that

equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment

is within acceptable limits



Royster-Clark Nitrogen has a comprehensive system to manage

changes to processes.  This system requires that changes to

items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology,

procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed

and authorized before being implemented.



D.  Worst Case Scenario:



The Environmental Protection Agency requires the worst case

scenario to be a catastrophic rupture of the terminal's

ammonia storage tank with a compete loss of product over 10

minutes. The tank is included in the facility's mechanical

integrity inspection and testing program.  Acoustic Emission

testing was completed in June of 1998.  The testing

indicated the tank to be in good condition.  Other safeguard

include pressure and temperature instrumentation, multipl

e

levels of relief devices, a refrigeration compressor system,

and well trained and experienced operators.  The EPA does

not allow any of these safeguards to be considered in the

worst case scenario.





In regard to worst case scenarios, EPA say's:



     "Because the assumptions required for the worst

     - case analysis are very conservative, the

     results likely will be very conservative.  These

     endpoints are concentrations below which it is

     believed nearly all individuals could be exposed

     for one-half hour to one hour without any

     serious health effects.  In addition,  the worst

     case analysis is carried out using very

     conservative assumptions about weather and

     release conditions.  The distance to the

     endpoint estimated under worst-case conditions

     should not be considered a zone in which the

     public would be likely in danger;  instead, it

     is intended to provide an estimate of the

     maximum possible area that might be affected in

     the unlikely event of catastrophic conditions.

     Distances greater than 10 kilometers are

     particularly uncertain.  EPA intends the

     estimated distances to provide a basis for

     discussion. rather than a basis for specific

     actions."





Because of the routine testing, in plant safety systems,

daily visual inspections, and intensive operations training,

Royster-Clark Nitrogen believes the worst case scenario to

be extremely unlikely to happen.



E.  Anhydrous Ammonia Alternative Scenario:



The conditions picked for the alternative case scenario are

those which would create a maximum amount of loss of

anhydrous ammonia from a vessel of ammonia.  The scenario

involves breakage of the sight glass and failure of the

ammonia check valve resulting in loss of 100 gallons of hot

anhydrous ammonia to the atmosphere.





F.  Five Year Accident History:



The Royster-Clark Nitrogen Meredosia Terminal has an

excellent safety re

cord with no deaths or serious injuries

to any of its personnel.  In addition, the terminal has

operated without a lost time accident for over twenty-five

years.



There  have  not been any incidents that meet the definition

of a RMP recordable release.



G.  Emergency Response:



The facility Emergency Action Plan covers accidental

releases of plant chemicals, natural disasters, emergency

response practices and procedures,   and  process safety

topics.  The plan is reviewed at least annually with all

employees.



u     All  permanent  employees  have  the  required  Hazmat

  training, including an eight hour refresher course annually.

  Each  employee and permanent contractor is trained on  the

  facility's  Emergency Response policies and procedures  at

  regularly scheduled plant safety meetings.



u     The  terminal manager and his assistant attend monthly

  Community Advisory Panel meetings. This panel includes other

  area  industries, Meredosia Village board  members,  local

  emergency   response  agencies,  community  leaders,   and

  citizens.



u    The Emergency Response Plan is followed in the event of

  an emergency. The emergency  alarm system is tested  once

  each month and an emergency drill is held at lease annually.





H.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



  The   Royster-Clark  Nitrogen  Meredosia   Terminal   will

  utilize   employee  input  and  industry  best  management

  practices  to  continuously improve safety, environmental,

  and all operations.



I.  Summary:



The Royster-Clark Nitrogen Meredosia Terminal and its

employees are extremely proud of its safety record and the

vast improvements in both safety and environmental.  We

believe that with the programs and policies in place in our

terminal and the continued efforts of 100% of our personnel,

we will be able to maintain our safety record and a safe

plant environment for all concerned in the years ahead.
